So, we're basically watching to see if this validators map is updated?  This seems a little dangerous in that we're assuming we have access to updates that are happening elsewhere, and it's possible we could also run into concurrency issues.
Is it possible to instead call a method like StableSubnetSubscriber.updateValidatorCount(final int new validatorCount) when the validator count changes?
Done.
Good catch.
Fixed.

I don't think we should call this on creation - it will wind up activating things during the construction phase before we finish wiring everything in.  I'd probably just wait for the first actual slot event.
Fair point. I was undecided.
Done.

This should wind up throwing a ConcurrentModificationException because you're adding a new subscription into the map while iterating over it. The unit tests aren't picking it up because they're only replacing one expired subscription so the loop immediately exits after the change. If there was another entry the call to next() would fail though.
I'd suggest just iterating through the existing subscriptions, removing any that have expired, then call adjustNumberOfSubscriptionsToNumberOfValidators to create as many more subscriptions as are now required.
Good catch.
I modified the test so that it would catch the exception, and it did. And I made the fix.

We should add a test to cover when the number of validators means we should subscribe to more subnets than exist. And for decreasing the number of validators when we still have enough to stay subscribed to all the subnets.
Also for decreasing the number of validators to 0.
I'd also suggest injecting the Random instance into StableSubnetSubscriber then you could inject one with a known seed (or a mock) and know which subscriptions should be added or removed.
Added all the tests you've suggested.

I do inject the Random object now, but I think it would be really complex to be able to mock which subscriptions should be added or removed, because we store the subnet id's in a set, and use streams to pick one random object from set.

For the shouldReplaceExpiredSubscriptionsWithNewOnes test, I decided to take your advice and try mocking the random object. It worked well for calculating the subscription slot in a visible fashion, but about the subnet ids, I noticed that the availableSubnetIndicesset is keeping them in order. I don't think my test should be depending on a Set keeping elements in order since I don't think its part of Set API to be kept in order. However, I'll keep it like it is for now because I feel like you might have another insight.
Reverted to not injecting the Random instance in light of the selection of subnets from a set stream.

This Api won't work when there are more than one validator client running.  It should just be a subscribeToPersistentSubnetSubscriptions.
I don't think we can provide an unsubscribe version because we don't know if another validator client still requires the subscription.  So if validators reduce we probably just need to wait for the subscription to expire.

Changed the naming of the method. My thinking was the same as yours. I'm planning to keep a superset of all subnet subscriptions at the beacon node side, and every time someone calls subscribeToPersistentSubnets I will add the subnetId's that are missing to the superset at BeaconNode and update the existing subscriptions with the max unsubscription slot
We only need to call this if we added subscriptions right?  We're currently calling this if we drop subscriptions as well.  We really only need to call this with the set of new subscriptions.
Good catch.
Fixed.
We should probably inspect the subscriptions - to make sure the subnets are distinct, and the unsubscribe slots are in bounds.

What if adjustNumberOfSubscriptionsToNumberOfValidators returns the new subscriptions, and if that set is non-empty we call validatorApiChannel.subscribeToPersistentSubnets?  The would mean we're requesting the minimum amount of work from the validatorApiChannel.
Great point. Made the change.
